Data Fetching

PhilJS provides powerful primitives for fetching, caching, and managing async data with built-in loading states, error handling, and automatic refetching.

Resources

Resources are the primary way to handle async data in PhilJS. They automatically track loading and error states, and re-fetch when dependencies change.

1import { createResource, createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function UserProfile() {
4  const [userId, setUserId] = createSignal(1);
5 
6  // Resource automatically refetches when userId changes
7  const [user] = createResource(userId, async (id) => {
8    const response = await fetch(`/api/users/${id}`);
9    return response.json();
10  });
11 
12  return (
13    <div>
14      {user.loading && <Spinner />}
15      {user.error && <Error message={user.error.message} />}
16      {user() && (
17        <div>
18          <h1>{user().name}</h1>
19          <p>{user().email}</p>
20        </div>
21      )}
22    </div>
23  );
24}

Resource States

Resources provide detailed state information:

1const [data, { mutate, refetch }] = createResource(source, fetcher);
2 
3// Accessor - returns the data or undefined
4data();
5 
6// Loading state
7data.loading;    // true while fetching
8data.state;      // 'pending' | 'ready' | 'refreshing' | 'errored'
9 
10// Error handling
11data.error;      // Error object if failed
12 
13// Latest value (even during refetch)
14data.latest;     // Previous value while refreshing
15 
16// Control functions
17refetch();       // Force refetch
18mutate(newData); // Update data optimistically

Suspense Integration

Resources integrate seamlessly with Suspense for declarative loading states:

1import { Suspense, createResource } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function App() {
4  return (
5    <Suspense fallback={<PageSkeleton />}>
6      <Dashboard />
7    </Suspense>
8  );
9}
10 
11function Dashboard() {
12  const [metrics] = createResource(async () => {
13    const res = await fetch('/api/metrics');
14    return res.json();
15  });
16 
17  // Component suspends until data is ready
18  return (
19    <div>
20      <MetricsGrid data={metrics()} />
21    </div>
22  );
23}

Error Boundaries

1import { ErrorBoundary, createResource } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function App() {
4  return (
5    <ErrorBoundary
6      fallback={(error, reset) => (
7        <div>
8          <p>Something went wrong: {error.message}</p>
9          <button onClick={reset}>Try again</button>
10        </div>
11      )}
12    >
13      <Suspense fallback={<Loading />}>
14        <DataComponent />
15      </Suspense>
16    </ErrorBoundary>
17  );
18}

Server Functions

Server functions allow you to run code on the server and call it from the client:

1// server/api.ts
2'use server';
3 
4import { db } from './db';
5 
6export async function getUsers() {
7  return db.users.findMany();
8}
9 
10export async function createUser(data: { name: string; email: string }) {
11  return db.users.create({ data });
12}
13 
14export async function deleteUser(id: string) {
15  return db.users.delete({ where: { id } });
16}
17 
18// client component
19import { getUsers, createUser, deleteUser } from './server/api';
20import { createResource } from 'philjs-core';
21 
22function UserList() {
23  const [users, { refetch }] = createResource(getUsers);
24 
25  const handleCreate = async () => {
26    await createUser({ name: 'New User', email: 'new@example.com' });
27    refetch();
28  };
29 
30  return (
31    <div>
32      {users()?.map(user => (
33        <UserCard key={user.id} user={user} onDelete={deleteUser} />
34      ))}
35      <button onClick={handleCreate}>Add User</button>
36    </div>
37  );
38}

Caching Strategies

1import { createResource, cache } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Simple in-memory cache
4const cachedFetch = cache(async (id: string) => {
5  const res = await fetch(`/api/items/${id}`);
6  return res.json();
7});
8 
9// Use cached function as fetcher
10const [item] = createResource(itemId, cachedFetch);
11 
12// Configure cache behavior
13const cachedWithOptions = cache(fetcher, {
14  // Cache key generator
15  key: (args) => args.join('-'),
16  // Time-to-live in milliseconds
17  ttl: 5 * 60 * 1000, // 5 minutes
18  // Stale-while-revalidate
19  staleWhileRevalidate: true,
20  // Maximum cache entries
21  maxSize: 100,
22});

Parallel & Sequential Fetching

1import { createResource, createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function Dashboard() {
4  // Parallel fetching - both start immediately
5  const [users] = createResource(fetchUsers);
6  const [products] = createResource(fetchProducts);
7  const [orders] = createResource(fetchOrders);
8 
9  return (
10    <Suspense fallback={<Loading />}>
11      <UsersWidget data={users()} />
12      <ProductsWidget data={products()} />
13      <OrdersWidget data={orders()} />
14    </Suspense>
15  );
16}
17 
18// Sequential fetching - one depends on another
19function UserOrders() {
20  const [userId] = createSignal(1);
21  const [user] = createResource(userId, fetchUser);
22 
23  // Only fetches after user is loaded
24  const [orders] = createResource(
25    () => user()?.id,
26    (id) => id && fetchOrdersForUser(id)
27  );
28 
29  return (
30    <Suspense fallback={<Loading />}>
31      <UserInfo user={user()} />
32      <OrdersList orders={orders() ?? []} />
33    </Suspense>
34  );
35}

Optimistic Updates

1import { createResource } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function TodoList() {
4  const [todos, { mutate, refetch }] = createResource(fetchTodos);
5 
6  const addTodo = async (text: string) => {
7    // Optimistically add the todo
8    const optimisticTodo = {
9      id: 'temp-' + Date.now(),
10      text,
11      done: false,
12    };
13    mutate(prev => [...(prev ?? []), optimisticTodo]);
14 
15    try {
16      // Actually create on server
17      const newTodo = await createTodo(text);
18      // Replace optimistic with real
19      mutate(prev =>
20        prev?.map(t => t.id === optimisticTodo.id ? newTodo : t) ?? []
21      );
22    } catch (error) {
23      // Rollback on error
24      mutate(prev => prev?.filter(t => t.id !== optimisticTodo.id) ?? []);
25      throw error;
26    }
27  };
28 
29  return (
30    <ul>
31      {todos()?.map(todo => (
32        <li key={todo.id}>{todo.text}</li>
33      ))}
34    </ul>
35  );
36}

Data Fetching in Rust

1use philjs::prelude::*;
2 
3#[component]
4fn UserProfile() -> Element {
5    let user_id = use_signal(|| 1u32);
6 
7    let user = use_resource(move || async move {
8        let id = user_id();
9        reqwest::get(&format!("/api/users/{}", id))
10            .await?
11            .json::<User>()
12            .await
13    });
14 
15    view! {
16        <Suspense fallback=|| view! { <Spinner /> }>
17            {move || user.read().map(|u| view! {
18                <div>
19                    <h1>{u.name}</h1>
20                    <p>{u.email}</p>
21                </div>
22            })}
23        </Suspense>
24    }
25}
26 
27// Server function
28#[server]
29async fn get_users() -> Result<Vec<User>, ServerError> {
30    let users = db::users::find_all().await?;
31    Ok(users)
32}

Pagination

1import { createResource, createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function PaginatedList() {
4  const [page, setPage] = createSignal(1);
5  const [pageSize] = createSignal(20);
6 
7  const [data] = createResource(
8    () => ({ page: page(), pageSize: pageSize() }),
9    async ({ page, pageSize }) => {
10      const res = await fetch(
11        `/api/items?page=${page}&pageSize=${pageSize}`
12      );
13      return res.json();
14    }
15  );
16 
17  return (
18    <div>
19      <Suspense fallback={<TableSkeleton />}>
20        <table>
21          {data()?.items.map(item => (
22            <tr key={item.id}>{/* ... */}</tr>
23          ))}
24        </table>
25      </Suspense>
26 
27      <Pagination
28        page={page()}
29        totalPages={data()?.totalPages ?? 1}
30        onPageChange={setPage}
31      />
32    </div>
33  );
34}

Infinite Scroll

1import { createSignal, createResource, onMount } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3function InfiniteList() {
4  const [items, setItems] = createSignal<Item[]>([]);
5  const [cursor, setCursor] = createSignal<string | null>(null);
6  const [hasMore, setHasMore] = createSignal(true);
7 
8  const [page, { refetch }] = createResource(
9    cursor,
10    async (cur) => {
11      const res = await fetch(
12        `/api/items${cur ? `?cursor=${cur}` : ''}`
13      );
14      return res.json();
15    }
16  );
17 
18  // Append new items when page loads
19  createEffect(() => {
20    const data = page();
21    if (data) {
22      setItems(prev => [...prev, ...data.items]);
23      setHasMore(data.hasMore);
24    }
25  });
26 
27  const loadMore = () => {
28    if (!page.loading && hasMore()) {
29      const lastItem = items().at(-1);
30      setCursor(lastItem?.id ?? null);
31    }
32  };
33 
34  return (
35    <div>
36      {items().map(item => (
37        <ItemCard key={item.id} item={item} />
38      ))}
39 
40      {page.loading && <Spinner />}
41 
42      {hasMore() && !page.loading && (
43        <button onClick={loadMore}>Load More</button>
44      )}
45    </div>
46  );
47}

Best Practices

  • Use Suspense boundaries: Wrap data-dependent UI for clean loading states
  • Implement error boundaries: Handle failures gracefully
  • Cache wisely: Balance freshness with performance
  • Optimize for waterfalls: Fetch data in parallel when possible
  • Use server functions: Keep sensitive logic on the server
